Current Market Volatility, Tariffs, and Your Investments

Dear [REDACTED:NAME]:

An airline pilot once described flying as “long stretches of boredom, interspersed with brief moments of sheer panic.” I am certainly not suggesting that you should be panicked about the recent tumult in the financial markets, however you may be wondering how all this is affecting your investments. 

President [REDACTED:NAME] made the imposition of tariffs on various US trading partners one of the central themes of his campaign. That part was known. However, uncertainty about the exact shape, size, and extent of the tariffs had kept financial markets in a constant state of unease since early February. Then, on April 2, President [REDACTED:NAME] announced a long list of countries on which tariffs would be imposed, with some of the largest levies falling on China—a trade nemesis during the first [REDACTED:NAME] administration—and the European Union. 

The equities markets reacted sharply to the announcement, with the S&P 500 falling almost 5% in one day.  When China announced retaliatory tariffs of 34% the next day the markets swooned again; the S&P 500 fell by about 6%, for a drop of more than 10% in value over two consecutive trading days. The downward trend and extreme volatility have continued into this week. 

So, how should investors respond to all this? Are there historical precedents that can provide some guidance? And what might investors expect in terms of eventual outcomes for their portfolios?

Market Volatility: Not “If,” but “When”

Those who have been invested in the markets for any length of time know that market volatility is—to use a phrase from software design—not a bug, but a feature. The financial markets represent the ongoing, collective decisions (rational and irrational) of millions of buyers and sellers all around the world. Prices move up or down as the millions of market participants around the world react to a constant flow of information. Sometimes, weeks or even months go by when very little happens; at other times dramatic movements can happen in mere hours. As shown in the chart below, market downturns have been a regular feature even as the stock market has posted strong long-term returns. 

SOURCE: Vanguard, Inc.

Timing the Market is Hazardous to Your Financial Health (and Impossible)

There is a well-known market proverb: “Time IN the market is more important than timing the market.” Even during pullbacks, corrections, or bear markets, investors who are committed and disciplined—even in the face of short-term downside volatility—have typically fared well over the longer term. 

The problem with market timing is that if you are not right 100% of the time you can lose a lot of money.  The chart below illustrates the experience of an investor who put $1 million into the stock market on January 1, 1990. If it was left in place until December 31, 2024, it would have grown to $34 million. If the investor had tried to time the market and missed just the ONE best day, the return would be $3.5 million lower ($30.5 million). Missing the 25 best days would have slashed $26.8 million off the portfolio return ($7.2 million) even though the investor’s daily market calls were correct an astonishing 99.67% of the time. 

For this reason, we continue to advise that the best way to reap the full long-term potential of your investments is to stay the course during turbulent periods and not be fooled into thinking that you (or anyone else) can correctly and consistently time the markets.

Market Resilience

Of course, this is not the first crisis that investors have had to contend with. It is instructive to examine the historical record which underscores the long-term resilience of markets in the face of many crises over time. The chart below shows how $1 invested in the MSCI World Index (a measure of total global stock markets) has grown over the past 54 years to almost $110 despite the temporary disruptions caused by crises as varied as the Arab oil embargo in 1973 to the Covid pandemic in 2022. Markets are frequently down in the immediate aftermath of such crises, but they have always recovered as the world adapts to new circumstances.

SOURCE: Dimensional Funds

Well-Diversified Portfolios Are Built for Times Like These

Of course, what ultimately matters to you is the performance of your portfolio. It is important to remember that we have designed your portfolio based on your individual circumstances, personal risk tolerance and specific goals. Diversification mitigates market volatility; while one part of the portfolio may be losing value at a given time, another part may be retaining or gaining in value. Your portfolio is diversified across several parameters – stocks versus bonds; the US versus international markets; developed markets versus emerging markets and public market versus private (alternative) investments.  

Here For You

Like you, I much prefer when markets are going up, but I want you to know that I am here for you when markets are down, as well. If you’d like to schedule some time to discuss any of this, you can drop me an [REDACTED:EMAIL] or use the link below to schedule.

7/15/2025 [REDACTED:ORG] Market Pulse Newsletter, Q2 2025 It is remarkable how much investor sentiment and market performance can shift in just a few months. The downturn and subsequent recovery were dizzying to say the least and left many investors scratching their heads. Those without a clear plan prior to the upheaval likely found themselves in a vulnerable, reactive position. In our view, it is important to put the current environment into a broader context. This helps us properly calibrate the portfolio and our reactions to the present reality without overemphasizing any single event or news item. Our goal is always to maintain a long-term mindset while remaining aware of the market’s ever-changing dynamics. This balance is difficult to achieve but of the utmost importance for achieving long-term investment success. As we noted in the last quarterly letter, not much has fundamentally changed in the economy since the start of the year. Rather, it is investors’ every changing perception and interpretation of current events that have driven the recent volatility. Even though the recent volatility has subsided, we don’t believe it is gone for good. During this time of relative calm, it is important to reflect on two timeless lessons. These are principles that most investors are forced to relearn every few years during turbulent periods. Revisiting these lessons can help investors avoid panicking when the next downturn inevitably arrives. It is Impossible to Time the Markets Staying invested is of paramount importance throughout market cycles. The problem with trying to time the market is not necessarily with the initial selling to avoid the downturn. The trouble usually occurs when attempting to buy back in. Investors get anchored to the recent lows and struggle to re-enter at higher prices during the recovery. The narrative is usually something like “This is a short-term bounce; the markets will retest the lows” or “I don’t want to chase the rally - I’ll wait for another dip to buy back in”. Investors are usually skeptical during the initial phases of a market recovery and believe they will be able to pick a bottom to buy back in. In our experience, more investors have lost more money trying to sidestep a downturn than from the downturn itself. The problem stems from the unbalanced nature of returns. Whereas the downside is limited to the amount invested (assuming no leverage), the upside returns are unlimited. In other words, the most that can be lost is the initial investment, but the amount that can be gained is theoretically infinite. Even though the potential upside can’t be measured as easily as the immediate losses, it is vastly more important and only achievable if you stay invested. Unfortunately, most people’s attention is focused on the easily measured losses which leads them to make inopportune investment decisions. They try to avoid a 20%-30% drawdown and end up missing out on making 2x, 3x, or even higher returns when the markets recover. This recent recovery is a perfect example. It basically came out of nowhere and if you were not prepared, you missed it. Not only did you lock in losses, but now you find yourself watching the market march higher while waiting for the “right time” to get back in. Invariably, these investors will relent and buy at significantly higher prices, missing out on most, if not all, of the subsequent gains. Importance of Asset Allocation Having the right asset allocation is the key to maintaining the necessary fortitude during times of stress and uncertainty. As a reminder, we entered the year with most portfolios having about 50% equity exposure with the balance allocated to fixed income, gold, structured notes and a significant cash position. This balanced allocation allowed us to be patient and calm during the most severe parts of the drawdown. A significant percentage of the portfolio was either offsetting or unrelated to the equity market performance, which provided much-needed stability. In addition, our goal is to focus the equity portfolio on what we believe are the highest quality companies we can find. In our experience these companies tend to lead the markets higher during recoveries. This focus gave us an additional level of comfort during the volatile downturn, enabling us to maintain and add to our equity exposure when most other investors were selling in a panic. Proactively preparing the portfolio for volatility before it comes is a significant aspect of our investment strategy. It has helped us limit downside in the past, enabled us to take advantage of opportunities, and assisted in the recovery of the portfolios. A Note on Structured Notes For most portfolios, we had a structured note that was called at the beginning of July and provided us with a 15% return in one year. This is the most recent example of a note performing as expected. Overall, our experience with the structured note allocation has been positive, and we continue to feel confident in their role within the portfolios. The current structured note portfolio is set up to provide us with somewhat predictable liquidity every few months. We believe that in aggregate, the notes will provide us with a satisfactory return and the liquidity we seek to take advantage of future opportunities. 7/15/2025 [REDACTED:ORG] Market Pulse Newsletter, Q2 2025

The past few months have demonstrated the significant shifts that can occur in investor sentiment and market performance. The recent market movements were considerable and may have caused some investors to feel uncertain. Individuals or entities without a defined investment strategy prior to significant market shifts may find themselves reacting rather than acting proactively. In our view, placing the current market environment within a broader historical and economic context is crucial. This approach assists us in evaluating market realities and calibrating portfolios, aiming to prevent overemphasis on any single event or news item. Our goal is to maintain a long-term investment mindset while remaining aware of the market’s evolving dynamics. Achieving this balance can be challenging but is generally considered highly important for potentially contributing to long-term investment success.

As we discussed in our last quarterly communication, in our view, fundamental economic conditions have not drastically altered since the beginning of the year. Instead, we believe that evolving investor perceptions and interpretations of current events have largely driven recent market volatility. While recent market fluctuations have lessened, we do not believe that market volatility is permanently absent. During periods of relative calm, it can be beneficial to consider enduring investment principles. These are lessons that investors may encounter repeatedly during turbulent periods. Reviewing these principles can help investors navigate future market downturns that may arise.

### The Challenges of Market Timing

Historically, remaining invested throughout market cycles has been widely considered a significant factor for long-term investment strategies. A common challenge with attempting to time the market lies not always in the initial decision to sell to avoid a downturn, but often in the subsequent attempt to re-enter. Investors may become anchored to recent low prices, finding it difficult to buy back into the market at higher levels during a recovery. Common internal narratives might include, "This is just a short-term bounce; the markets will retest the lows," or "I don't want to chase the rally—I'll wait for another dip to buy back in." During the early stages of a market recovery, investors often exhibit skepticism and may believe they can accurately predict the bottom for re-entry.

Based on our observations, attempts to time the market by sidestepping downturns have, in many cases, resulted in missed opportunities during subsequent recoveries, potentially leading to less favorable outcomes than remaining invested. This challenge partly stems from the asymmetrical nature of market returns: while potential downside is limited to the amount invested (assuming no leverage), the potential for upside returns is theoretically unlimited. In other words, the maximum potential loss is the initial investment, but the amount that can be gained has no theoretical upper bound. Although potential upside may not be as easily quantifiable as immediate losses, it can be a vastly important consideration and is generally only achievable by remaining invested. Unfortunately, many investors' attention may be drawn to easily measured losses, which can lead to potentially inopportune investment decisions. Attempts to avoid drawdowns, such as 20% or 30%, can risk missing out on significant potential gains during market recoveries, as historically observed.

The recent market recovery serves as an illustration. Its rapid ascent may have surprised some investors, and those not positioned in the market may have missed out on initial gains. For investors who exited the market, the challenge often becomes re-entering at an opportune time. Waiting for the "right time" can lead to watching the market advance and potentially re-entering at higher prices, thus potentially foregoing a portion of subsequent gains. This scenario highlights a common challenge in market timing.

### The Role of Asset Allocation

Establishing an appropriate asset allocation strategy can be instrumental in fostering resilience during periods of market stress and uncertainty. As a reminder, as of the beginning of the year, many portfolios managed by [REDACTED:ORG] generally maintained an approximate 50% equity exposure, with the remainder allocated to diversified assets such as fixed income, gold, structured notes, and a significant cash position. This diversified allocation was designed to contribute to patience and stability during challenging market conditions. A notable portion of these portfolios comprised assets intended to offer diversification or exhibit a lower correlation to equity market performance, thereby aiming to potentially enhance portfolio stability.

Furthermore, within the equity component of portfolios, our goal is to focus on companies we identify as high-quality. Based on our experience, we observe that companies we classify as high-quality often tend to perform favorably during market recoveries. This strategic focus was intended to provide a measure of confidence during the volatile downturn, which assisted us in maintaining and selectively adding to equity exposure when market sentiment was broadly negative. Proactively structuring portfolios for potential volatility is a significant aspect of our investment strategy. While past performance is not indicative of future results, this approach is designed to help mitigate downside risk, enable the capture of potential opportunities, and support portfolio recovery. There is no guarantee that any investment strategy will achieve its objectives.

### A Note on Structured Notes

As an example, some portfolios managed by [REDACTED:ORG] held a structured note that was called at the beginning of July, which resulted in an approximate 15% return over one year for those specific holdings. **Please note that past performance is not indicative of future results, and there is no guarantee that similar results will be achieved.** This serves as an illustration of a structured note potentially performing in line with its design parameters. Our experience with structured note allocations has been generally positive, and we continue to evaluate their potential role within diversified portfolios.

The current structured note portfolio is designed with the objective of providing periodic liquidity, though actual liquidity and timing may vary. We aim for the aggregate structured note allocation to contribute to our objectives for return and liquidity, which we seek to utilize for potential future opportunities. However, structured notes involve various risks, and their performance is not guaranteed.

**Q: What is financial planning?**
Financial planning is the process of creating a plan to align your financial resources with your personal goals. This process is often completed with the support of a professional financial planner.

At [REDACTED:ORG], financial planning means following our comprehensive financial planning process, which we refer to as the [REDACTED:ORG] approach, to help you:

*   Identify Financial Goals
*   Conduct a Financial Analysis
*   Implement Your Financial Plan
*   Construct an Investment Portfolio
*   Create a Safety Net
*   Plan a Legacy
*   Hold Regular Financial Checkups

Learn more in the Our Process section of our website.

**Q: What services do you offer?**
Our comprehensive financial planning services are designed to be tailored to your unique needs. Depending on your specific situation, these services may include:

*   Financial goal planning
*   Cash flow planning
*   Investment planning
*   Retirement income planning
*   Tax planning considerations
*   Education planning
*   Risk management
*   Estate and legacy planning considerations

Learn more in the Services section of our website.

**Q: Do you offer investment management?**
Yes. Investment planning, which includes managing your investments (also known as investment management), is offered as part of our comprehensive financial planning services.

**Q: How do you charge for your services?**
In most cases, we charge for our comprehensive financial planning services through an Assets Under Management (AUM) fee. This fee is calculated as a percentage of the total value of the investments we manage on your behalf. The percentage typically begins at a higher rate and may reduce as the value of your managed investments grows. Our AUM fees are negotiated on a case-by-case basis and will not exceed 1.5% annually.

**Q: Do you have a minimum investment account size?**
Our investment management services and portfolios are generally best-suited for accounts with a value over $250,000.

**Q: Do you offer a free consultation?**
Yes. We are always interested in connecting with new individuals who may be a good fit for our comprehensive financial planning services. You are welcome to schedule a complimentary, 30-minute introductory call with an [REDACTED:ORG] financial planner today.

**Q: Are you a fiduciary?**
Yes. As a Registered Investment Adviser (RIA), [REDACTED:ORG] and its Investment Adviser Representatives have a fiduciary responsibility to act in our clients’ best interests. Additionally, “Act as a Fiduciary” is one of the six core values that guide our business decisions and day-to-day interactions. We view acting as a fiduciary as fundamental to our approach, beyond simply a regulatory obligation.

**Q: What are your qualifications, licenses, or designations?***
[REDACTED:ORG] is a Registered Investment Adviser (RIA) registered with the [REDACTED:ORG]. As an RIA, the firm and its Investment Adviser Representatives (IARs) are held to a fiduciary standard when providing advisory services.

Our financial planners serve as Investment Adviser Representatives of [REDACTED:ORG]. Additionally, some of our financial planners may also be registered representatives of [REDACTED:ORG], which is registered with [REDACTED:ORG]. When acting in their capacity as registered representatives, they are held to a suitability standard.

Our financial planners hold various licenses and certifications relevant to their roles, which may include the Securities Industry Essentials® (SIE®) certification, Series 7, and Series 66.

Several professional designations are held among our team of financial planners. These include the CERTIFIED FINANCIAL PLANNER™ (CFP®), Certified Private Wealth Advisor® (CPWA®), and Behavioral Financial Advisor (BFA™) designations.

**Q: What is a CFP® professional?**
A CFP® professional is a financial planner who has earned the CERTIFIED FINANCIAL PLANNER™ designation. This designation is awarded to individuals who meet rigorous standards in education, examination, experience, and ethics. CFP® professionals commit to serving as fiduciaries, acting in their client’s best interests at all times.

The [REDACTED:ORG] Team currently includes six CFP® professionals:

**Q: What is your investment philosophy?**
Our investment philosophy can be summarized as: We are not bullish, we are not bearish; we are process-driven.

We employ systematic processes to guide our investment decision-making, aiming to help mitigate emotional influences in investing. Through our disciplined processes, we strive to provide well-considered, tax-efficient, and globally diversified investment portfolios that are designed to suit our clients’ individual needs and objectives.

**Q: Where will my accounts be held?**
Client investment accounts are custodied, or held, at [REDACTED:ORG]. All clients are provided with a login to the [REDACTED:ORG] online platform for account access.

**Q: Will I have online access to my accounts?**
All [REDACTED:ORG] clients are provided with a unique and private login to view and access their accounts through the [REDACTED:ORG] online platform.

Additionally, [REDACTED:ORG] clients have access to our Client Portal, which is powered by [REDACTED:ORG]. This portal provides online access to personalized portfolio information, investment reporting, and document retrieval. This may include Client Meeting Notes (your Plans of Action), [REDACTED:ORG] account statements, and [REDACTED:ORG] 1099 tax documents.

Page 1 – Text

Section heading (left column)
Financially smart for employers

One of the most exciting aspects of these plans is they’re structured with the employer’s bottom line in mind. Many offer:

• Payroll tax savings through smart plan design
• Reduced strain on traditional insurance, contributing to lower renewals, including workers’ comp
• There is no direct cost to the employer. In fact, due to how 125 cafeteria plans are designed, the employer may have a net payroll tax gain.

These advantages make supplemental health plans especially powerful for small and mid-sized businesses that want to provide stronger benefits without incurring additional costs.

In addition to upfront savings, these plans may also provide long-term financial advantages. By shifting routine care away from high-cost claims channels — such as ER visits and specialist offices — employers may see improved utilization patterns that promote better underwriting outcomes, stronger renewal positions, and, in some cases, even eligibility for year-end plan refunds. When structured correctly, these plans not only enhance value for employees, but also increase efficiency and predictability for the business — a rare combination in today’s benefits landscape.

⸻

Section heading (upper right column)
A strategic talent advantage

We’re in a new era of employment marketing, where benefits communicate culture. Offering a supplemental health plan that prioritizes everyday care tells your employees, “We see you. We support you. We’re investing in your health.”

In industries with high turnover, hourly labor, or seasonal staff, these plans are transformative. They enhance retention, elevate morale, and assist businesses in distinguishing themselves within a competitive talent market.

⸻

Subheading (mid-right column)
An advisor’s opportunity

This moment represents a unique opportunity for brokers, advisors and consultants to lead with strategy. Supplemental doesn’t mean secondary anymore. It means smart, scalable and sustainable. Whether layered onto existing group plans or offered as stand-alone benefits, these modern solutions open the door to meaningful client impact.

The right supplemental strategy gives advisors a platform to showcase innovation and leadership. Instead of concentrating solely on price or plan comparisons, brokers can orient clients toward comprehensive solutions that align with their workforce demographics and evolving expectations. In doing so, they maintain existing relationships, strengthen them, and create new opportunities for advanced growth.

In a world where every dollar counts and every employee matters, bridging the benefits gap is not only possible but essential. With the right supplemental strategy, it’s well within reach.

⸻

**Financially strategic for employers**

These plans are designed with an employer's financial considerations in mind. Many may offer:

*   Potential payroll tax efficiencies through effective plan design
*   The possibility of reduced strain on traditional insurance, which could contribute to more favorable renewals, including for workers’ compensation
*   For employers, there may be no direct premium cost. In fact, due to the structure of 125 cafeteria plans, employers could potentially realize a net payroll tax benefit.

These potential advantages can make supplemental health plans a valuable consideration for small and mid-sized businesses seeking to offer enhanced benefits, potentially without significant additional direct premium outlays.

Beyond immediate tax efficiencies, these plans may also contribute to long-term financial advantages. By helping to shift routine care away from higher-cost claims channels—such as emergency room visits and specialist offices—employers might observe improved utilization patterns. This, in turn, could support better underwriting outcomes, strengthen renewal positions, and, in some instances, even lead to eligibility for year-end plan refunds. When implemented thoughtfully, these plans have the potential to not only enhance employee value but also contribute to increased efficiency and predictability for the business—a beneficial combination in today’s benefits landscape.

---

**A strategic talent advantage**

We recognize that today's employment market values benefits that reflect a supportive culture. Offering a supplemental health plan that prioritizes accessible, everyday care can convey to employees, “We understand your needs. We support your well-being. We are investing in your health.”

In sectors characterized by high turnover, hourly labor, or seasonal staffing, these plans can be highly impactful. They may contribute to enhanced retention, uplift morale, and assist businesses in differentiating themselves within a competitive talent market.

---

**An advisor’s opportunity**

This moment presents a distinct opportunity for brokers, advisors, and consultants to lead with strategic benefits solutions. Supplemental benefits are no longer merely secondary; they represent an opportunity for smart, scalable, and sustainable strategies. Whether integrated into existing group plans or offered as stand-alone benefits, these modern solutions can facilitate meaningful client impact.

A well-considered supplemental strategy can provide advisors a platform to demonstrate innovation and leadership. Rather than solely focusing on price or basic plan comparisons, advisors can guide clients toward comprehensive solutions that align with their workforce demographics and evolving expectations. This approach can help maintain and strengthen existing client relationships, and potentially create new opportunities for advanced growth.

In an environment where financial resources are carefully managed and employee well-being is paramount, addressing the benefits gap is not only possible but increasingly important. With the right supplemental strategy, this objective can be well within reach.

---

**Caption in colored box**

Even with employer-sponsored insurance, many employees are still forgoing necessary care.

**Key Changes and Compliance Rationale:**

1.  **"Financially smart" to "Financially strategic":** "Strategic" is more measured and professional than "smart," avoiding subjective superlatives.
2.  **"One of the most exciting aspects" removed:** "Exciting" is a subjective, promotional term that can sound exaggerated.
3.  **"Payroll tax savings" to "Potential payroll tax efficiencies":** Adds the necessary qualifier "potential" and uses "efficiencies" which is slightly less absolute than "savings."
4.  **"Reduced strain" to "The possibility of reduced strain" and "contributing to lower renewals" to "could contribute to more favorable renewals":** Added qualifiers "possibility" and "could" to avoid guaranteeing outcomes. "More favorable" is also a softer claim than "lower."
5.  **"There is no direct cost to the employer" to "For employers, there may be no direct premium cost":** This is a critical change. "No direct cost" is a very strong claim that is likely untrue if administrative costs are considered. Specifying "premium cost" and adding "may be" makes it more accurate and compliant.
6.  **"employer may have a net payroll tax gain" to "employers could potentially realize a net payroll tax benefit":** "Could potentially realize" is slightly more cautious than "may have," and "benefit" is a bit broader than "gain," which sometimes implies a profit.
7.  **"especially powerful" to "a valuable consideration":** Tone down hyperbolic language.
8.  **"without incurring additional costs" to "potentially without significant additional direct premium outlays":** Again, clarifies that this refers to *premium* costs and adds "potentially" and "significant" to manage expectations around administrative burdens.
9.  **"not only enhance value... but also increase efficiency" to "have the potential to not only enhance value... but also contribute to increased efficiency":** Emphasizes potential and contribution rather than absolute causation.
10. **"transformative" to "can be highly impactful":** Replaced a strong, potentially exaggerated term with a more measured one.
11. **"They enhance retention, elevate morale, and assist businesses" to "They may contribute to enhanced retention, uplift morale, and assist businesses":** Added "may contribute to" for qualification.
12. **"meaningful client impact" to "facilitate meaningful client impact":** "Facilitate" implies enabling, rather than direct guarantee.
13. **"gives advisors a platform" to "can provide advisors a platform":** Added "can" to imply potential.
14. **"create new opportunities for advanced growth" to "potentially create new opportunities for advanced growth":** Added "potentially."
15. **"possible but essential. With the right supplemental strategy, it’s well within reach" to "possible but increasingly important. With the right supplemental strategy, this objective can be well within reach":** Small tweaks to make it slightly less absolute while retaining the positive outlook.
16. **Overall:** Increased use of qualifying language (e.g., "may," "could," "potential," "might," "can," "possibly," "tend to") to avoid promising specific outcomes and to reflect the conditional nature of financial results.

Advisors and planning styles vary widely. The scope of services, the depth of analysis, and even the advisor’s strategic philosophy can differ significantly--and so can the results. While cost is often a consideration, it’s important to recog- nize that value isn’t always visible on the surface. What may appear to be a simple, low-cost solution could end Finding Your Starting Point for a Winning Retirement 2 up falling short if it lacks the structure or support needed for the complexities of retirement. That’s why choosing the right kind of financial guidance--and the right kind of relationship--matters. We believe asking the right questions can help reveal the path that fits you best--and ensure that your financial guid- ance matches the life you want to live. 3 Evaluating The Self-Managed Approach M any individuals take pride in handling their own investments and financial decisions. When retirement introduces new layers of complexity, including tax efficiency, income planning, and healthcare costs, it’s important to re-assess if this will continue to be prudent. Manual Research and Analysis vs. Professional-Grade Software Tools Some are comfortable with relying on intensive efforts in research and utilizing publicly available resources in self-managing their finances. Others insist upon the edge of highly proficient professionals using an array of advisor-exclusive, professional-grade software tools to produce detailed data and projections that support a precise and informed strategy. Finding Your Starting Point for a Winning Retirement 4 Self-Reliance vs. Professional Team Oversight Some value the autonomy of self-managing finances, trusting their retirement to their personal efforts. Others find confidence in the collaborative oversight-- maintaining ownership of their plan while benefiting from a team who brings added insight, accountability, and coordination. Solo Stewardship vs. Shared Continuity For those who manage everything themselves, the plan often lives in their head or on their desktop. Others recognize the peace of mind that comes with a team already up to speed--ready to support a spouse or family if needed, without scrambling or starting from scratch. Subject Matter Mastery vs. Holistic Expertise Some individuals have achieved success with a solid knowledge of investment strategies. They may be tempted to tackle the complexity of the new challenges that come with retirement planning. Others prefer a professional that is well versed in the latest developments involving tax codes, cash-flow planning, RMD rules, estate planning, Medicare timelines, and more. Beyond an investment strategy, all of these aspects of financial planning benefit from strategic holistic balancing. 5 Comparison Shopping for an Advisor W hether you already have an advisor or are currently exploring your options, it’s important to recognize that not all advisors offer the same level of planning. What may appear similar on the surface often differs significantly in depth, process, and philosophy. Sales Pitch vs. Insights Talented salespeople might be helpful for those that require less information and a more directed approach towards their future. Others prefer a relationship with a process based upon personalized in-depth insights and patient guidance towards clearly defined goals. An Individual Advisor vs. A Team Approach Many advisors operate independently, even within the same firm, each earning their own commissions based upon their clients they each individually serve and support. Finding Your Starting Point for a Winning Retirement 6 Others provide clients a dedicated contact backed by a team of experienced professionals who collaborate as one advisor team--fully aligned and incentivized to focus on your success. Team members compensated by salary reinforce the team’s focus on customers, not commissions. Cost Consideration vs. Value Realization There are numerous ways financial professionals are compensated. When evaluating the investment, it’s important to understand all fees and carefully evaluate the value provided. While some advisors will focus on potential rates of returns, a holistic planning relationship can lead to optimized tax strategies, tailored investment approaches, and a quantifiable justification that outweighs the fees. Ultimately, the least expensive option may not offer the greatest value. Generalist vs. Focused Specialist Most financial advisors are willing to accept any client willing to work with them, regardless of what their financial needs are. Without boundaries, they may sell car insurance, college savings plans, starter investment plans and even a templated retirement plan. They fulfill a vital role in serving the mass market, without minimums or qualifiers. [REDACTED:NAME], CFP(R) 7 A smaller number of financial firms serve a specific niche and are selective in accepting only clients who fit within their field of expertise--where they can offer the most value. These firms specialize in working with a particular type of client--whether it’s working with specific corporate retirement plans, high-net-worth individuals, or those with complex legacy planning needs. By narrowing their scope, they’re able to provide more detailed analysis, strategic guidance, and specialized care than most generalist advisors. Locked In vs. No Commitments Some advisory relationships involve financial products that come with long-term commitments or hidden restrictions that can hinder your access to your money and limit financial flexibility. Upfront Load Fees and early termination penalties could have serious consequences. Others take a different approach--earning trust and loyalty through service, not contracts or upfront fees. A no-commitment model allows clients to retain full control of their accounts, with the freedom to make changes without penalties or obligations. 9 Types of Financial Plans T he term “financial plan” can mean very different things--ranging from a general outline of future expectations to a detailed, evolving strategy. Understanding the differences can help you choose the type of plan--and advisor--that best matches your needs. Transactional vs. Relational Many advisors have a business model built on a sales transaction of a one-time financial plan which might include the sale of a financial product. A static plan may offer a sense of direction that serves as a starting point and offers little in the way of course corrections over time. A different dynamic is found in the ongoing support of an advisor relationship, and it appeals to those that wish to have consistent professional oversight to keep a financial plan on target and optimized through changing financial, tax and market landscapes as well as life changes. Finding Your Starting Point for a Winning Retirement 10 Investment-Only vs. Holistic Integration Some advisors create investment plans focused solely on growth or protection and may consider that the extent of a financial plan. While that may be one important component, it leaves out crucial elements. A holistic strategy integrates tax planning, income sequencing, healthcare costs, and legacy goals into a unified framework--where each part supports and reinforces the others. When financial decision-making is done in isolation, important connections are often missed. Goals-Based vs. Cash Flow-Centered Planning Goals-based planning is often centered around future milestones-- such as retiring by a certain age or reaching a savings goal. While this helps define purpose, it can fall short when it doesn’t account for the practical logistics of turning savings into income. Cash flow-based planning addresses this by mapping the inflows and outflows of money throughout retirement--tracking not only how much is needed, but when and how it should be distributed. It accounts for timing, taxes, and long-term sustainability, aligning the plan more closely with the day-to-day realities of retirement living. Simplified vs. Advanced Technology-Driven Some financial plans amount to a rough sketch-- perhaps a quick projection or self-made spreadsheet [REDACTED:NAME], CFP(R) 11 estimating retirement income. These may provide basic direction but often lack depth and adaptability. More advanced approaches involve powerful technology that analyzes hundreds of variables--stress-testing income strategies, modeling tax impacts, and projecting future scenarios with far greater accuracy. While a simplified plan might help answer “when can I retire?”, a technology-driven strategy focuses on how to protect, grow, and transfer wealth with intention. Leveraging technology allows a plan’s success rate to be tested against multiple threats for the full span of retirement and beyond. 13 Choosing the Right Path Forward T here’s no one-size-fits-all approach to retirement planning. What matters most is that the guidance you choose reflects the complexity of your financial life and aligns with the level of support you want moving forward. Whether you’re managing things on your own, working with an advisor, or somewhere in between, this may be the moment to ask: Does my current approach give me the clarity, confidence, and adaptability I’ll need--not just to retire, but to make the most of what’s possible throughout retirement? 1 Finding Your Starting Point for a Successful Retirement Journey

Intro
There’s no universal path to retirement success. Some people prefer to manage things themselves, staying in control of their investments and decisions. Others seek out an advisor for expert input or a second opinion. And some choose to form an ongoing relationship with a professional who can help guide them through every stage—investments, taxes, income strategies, and legacy planning.

Advisors and planning styles vary widely. Some offer limited investment guidance, while others take a more comprehensive approach that integrates tax planning, estate strategy, and long-term income design. The scope of services, the depth of analysis, and even the advisor’s strategic philosophy can differ significantly—potentially impacting the outcomes. While cost is often a consideration, it’s important to recognize that value isn’t always visible on the surface. What may appear to be a simple, low-cost solution could end Finding Your Starting Point for a Successful Retirement Journey 2 up falling short if it lacks the structure or support needed for the complexities of retirement. That’s why choosing the right kind of financial guidance—and the right kind of relationship—matters. We believe asking the right questions can help reveal the path that fits you best—and ensure that your financial guidance matches the life you want to live.

3 Evaluating The Self-Managed Approach
Many individuals take pride in handling their own investments and financial decisions. When retirement introduces new layers of complexity, including tax efficiency, income planning, and healthcare costs, it’s important to re-assess if this will continue to be prudent.

Manual Research and Analysis vs. Professional-Grade Software Tools
Some are comfortable with relying on intensive efforts in research and utilizing publicly available resources in self-managing their finances. Others consider the potential benefits of professionals utilizing an array of advisor-exclusive, professional-grade software tools to produce detailed data and projections that support a precise and informed strategy.

Finding Your Starting Point for a Successful Retirement Journey 4
Self-Reliance vs. Professional Team Oversight
Some value the autonomy of self-managing finances, trusting their retirement to their personal efforts. Others find confidence in the collaborative oversight—maintaining ownership of their plan while benefiting from a team who brings added insight, accountability, and coordination.

Solo Stewardship vs. Shared Continuity
For those who manage everything themselves, the plan often lives in their head or on their desktop. Others recognize the peace of mind that comes with a team already up to speed—ready to support a spouse or family if needed, without scrambling or starting from scratch.

Subject Matter Mastery vs. Holistic Expertise
Some individuals have achieved success with a solid knowledge of investment strategies. They may be tempted to tackle the complexity of the new challenges that come with retirement planning. Others prefer a professional that is well versed in the latest developments involving tax codes, cash-flow planning, RMD rules, estate planning, Medicare timelines, and more. Beyond an investment strategy, all of these aspects of financial planning benefit from strategic holistic balancing.

5 Comparison Shopping for an Advisor
Whether you already have an advisor or are currently exploring your options, it’s important to recognize that not all advisors offer the same level of planning. What may appear similar on the surface often differs significantly in depth, process, and philosophy.

Focused Guidance vs. Broad-Brush Advice
Some approaches might be suitable for those seeking a more directed path. Others prefer a relationship with a process based upon personalized in-depth insights and patient guidance towards clearly defined goals.

An Individual Advisor vs. A Team Approach
Many advisors operate independently, even within the same firm, each earning their own compensation based upon the clients they individually serve and support. Finding Your Starting Point for a Successful Retirement Journey 6 Others provide clients a dedicated contact backed by a team of experienced professionals who collaborate as one advisor team—working together with a shared focus on client goals. Team members compensated by salary reinforce the team’s focus on clients, not commissions.

Cost Consideration vs. Value Realization
There are numerous ways financial professionals are compensated. When evaluating the investment, it’s important to understand all fees and carefully evaluate the value provided. While some advisors will focus on potential rates of returns, a holistic planning relationship can offer tax-efficient strategies, tailored investment approaches, and potential value that can often exceed the fees. Ultimately, the least expensive option may not offer the greatest value.

Generalist vs. Focused Specialist
Most financial advisors are willing to accept any client willing to work with them, regardless of what their financial needs are. Without boundaries, they may sell car insurance, college savings plans, starter investment plans, and even a templated retirement plan. They fulfill a vital role in serving the mass market, without minimums or qualifiers. [REDACTED:NAME], CFP(R) 7 A smaller number of financial firms serve a specific niche and are selective in accepting clients who align with their field of expertise. These firms specialize in working with a particular type of client—whether it’s working with specific corporate retirement plans, high-net-worth individuals, or those with complex legacy planning needs. This specialization often enables a deeper understanding and more tailored strategies for their specific client needs.

Structured Engagements vs. Flexible Service
Some advisory relationships involve financial products that come with long-term commitments or restrictions that can hinder your access to your money and limit financial flexibility. Upfront Load Fees and early termination penalties could have serious consequences. Others take a different approach—earning trust and loyalty through service, not long-term contracts or upfront fees. A flexible service model allows clients to retain control of their accounts, with the freedom to make changes without undue penalties or obligations.

9 Types of Financial Plans
The term “financial plan” can mean very different things—ranging from a general outline of future expectations to a detailed, evolving strategy. Understanding the differences can help you choose the type of plan—and advisor—that best matches your needs.

Transactional vs. Relational
Many advisors have a business model built on a sales transaction of a one-time financial plan which might include the sale of a financial product. A static plan may offer a sense of direction that serves as a starting point and offers little in the way of course corrections over time. A different dynamic is found in the ongoing support of an advisor relationship, and it appeals to those that wish to have consistent professional oversight to keep a financial plan on target and adapted and refined through changing financial, tax, and market landscapes, as well as life changes.

Finding Your Starting Point for a Successful Retirement Journey 10
Investment-Only vs. Holistic Integration
Some advisors create investment plans focused solely on growth or protection and may consider that the extent of a financial plan. While that may be one important component, it leaves out crucial elements. A holistic strategy integrates tax planning, income sequencing, healthcare costs, and legacy goals into a unified framework—where each part supports and reinforces the others. When financial decision-making is done in isolation, important connections are often missed.

Goals-Based vs. Cash Flow-Centered Planning
Goals-based planning is often centered around future milestones—such as retiring by a certain age or reaching a savings goal. While this helps define purpose, it can fall short when it doesn’t account for the practical logistics of turning savings into income. Cash flow-based planning addresses this by mapping the inflows and outflows of money throughout retirement—tracking not only how much is needed, but when and how it should be distributed. It accounts for timing, taxes, and long-term sustainability, aligning the plan more closely with the day-to-day realities of retirement living.

Simplified vs. Advanced Technology-Driven
Some financial plans amount to a rough sketch—perhaps a quick projection or self-made spreadsheet [REDACTED:NAME], CFP(R) 11 estimating retirement income. These may provide basic direction but often lack depth and adaptability. More advanced approaches involve powerful technology that analyzes hundreds of variables—stress-testing income strategies, modeling tax impacts, and projecting future scenarios with enhanced precision. While a simplified plan might help answer “when can I retire?”, a technology-driven strategy focuses on how to protect, grow, and transfer wealth with intention. Leveraging technology allows a plan’s potential sustainability to be evaluated against various scenarios for the full span of retirement and beyond.

13 Choosing the Right Path Forward
There’s no one-size-fits-all approach to retirement planning. What matters most is that the guidance you choose reflects the complexity of your financial life and aligns with the level of support you want moving forward.

Whether you’re managing things on your own, working with an advisor, or somewhere in between, this may be the moment to ask: Does my current approach give me the clarity, confidence, and adaptability I’ll need—not just to retire, but to make the most of what’s possible throughout retirement? If you’re seeking a deeper, more integrated approach—one that’s designed to grow with you, adjust to life’s unknowns, and support your goals with strategy and care—the path forward may become clearer.

Financial Fundamentals – Estate Planning Essentials 

By [REDACTED:NAME], CFP®, BFA™

What’s Included:

What happens if you don’t have an estate plan?

Core documents of an estate plan

Often-overlooked estate planning elements

Maintaining your estate plan

When to consider working with an estate planning professional

The bottom line

During an initial conversation with a prospective client, a financial planner will almost always inquire about their estate planning needs. The reason is that you can learn a lot about what matters to someone from their end-of-life desires. However, more often than not, the people we speak with do not have an estate plan, or any of the basic documents that comprise one. Even as a Financial Planner, I, too, am guilty of this. It is not always easy to consider what life would be like, even from a strictly financial standpoint, after you are gone.

An estate plan is a set of documents meant to clearly define how your assets will flow from one generation to the next. The purpose of this is to ease the process for your loved ones after you pass. In this edition of the Financial Fundamentals series, I will discuss the various documents that comprise an estate plan, including wills, trusts, financial powers of attorney, and healthcare directives, as well as their importance.

What Happens if I Don’t Have an Estate Plan?

According to [REDACTED:ORG], less than half of adults in the U.S., only 46%, have a will. This percentage has remained similar since 1990. For over three decades, despite advancements in technology and increased access to financial services and information, people continue to overlook the value of having an estate plan. Not having an estate plan can result in several consequences, including your after-death wishes not being fulfilled.

If you pass away without an estate plan, the distribution of your assets will be decided in court, which can be a lengthy and expensive process for your loved ones. This leaves your legacy in the hands of a detached legal system. This is called dying “intestate.”

Simply put, intestate means you die without a will, and your loved ones will have to go through the probate process for intestate succession. The probate process occurs even if you have a will, but without a will to guide it, the process is much more arduous. 

A probate court is a court with jurisdiction to handle the enforcement and administration of estates and property. They handle the “probate” of wills, trusts, guardianship, and all of your estate planning documents. They also hold the estates of intestate deaths. 

Each state has varying processes and laws for intestate deaths. For all states, though, if you die without a will, the state makes one for you. Then, once your estate goes through probate, the inheritor must file a petition to justify why they have a claim to all or a portion of the estate. Multiple people can file a petition, and based on the case and information provided, the court decides on how the remaining assets will be distributed. 

This entire process can be long and financially taxing on your loved ones. Not only are there legal fees for the probate process, but the estate’s value can change because of how long the process can take. This often leaves inheritors with less than they may have expected, which can cause frustration and anger. 

Dying intestate can have a significant emotional toll on your loved ones. The probate process is highly stressful, made worse by the fact that someone they loved has passed away. The probate process can also pit family members against one another, leading to increased emotional strain. The way to avoid this is by having a thoughtful and thorough estate plan. 

Core Documents of an Estate Plan

What is a Will?

A will is a legal document that provides direction on where you want your assets and property to be distributed upon your death. Wills are typically put together by an attorney, although there are some boilerplate wills that you can find online, which do not require an attorney to draft.

For families with young or special-needs children, a will is crucial for designating a guardian. Without a will, the courts will decide who should care for any minor or special needs children. In some cases, this may conflict with the parents’ wishes.

One critical item about wills, which many people don’t understand, is that account beneficiaries trump wills. Therefore, if you have beneficiaries listed on your accounts, your assets will be distributed directly to those beneficiaries, bypassing your will entirely. 

In other words, you could spend a significant amount of effort and money creating an elaborate will that will play out all of your wishes, but if it is not executed correctly on your account beneficiary forms, it won’t matter. This is why it is essential to revisit and, if necessary, update your beneficiary elections once you have completed your will.

What is a Trust?

A common estate planning question is, “Do I need a trust?” Sure, having a trust sounds fancy, but in many cases, if you have a simple estate plan, a trust may not be necessary. 

One reason a trust is almost always recommended is if you have minor children. A trust can be a powerful tool for providing direction and protecting assets to ensure a minor heir is taken care of. 

Another reason a trust might make sense for you is if you own property in another state. In that case, a trust may help your heirs avoid probate in the state in which the property is owned. 

According to [REDACTED:ORG], a revocable trust can help avoid probate in each state where property is owned. A revocable trust allows you to transfer ownership of these properties to the trust during your lifetime, streamlining the process after death. Trusts remain private, unlike wills, protecting the privacy of your estate and beneficiaries. In the event of your incapacity, a revocable trust allows your beneficiaries to manage your properties without court interference. And, a revocable trust can be changed at any point while you’re alive.

What is a Financial Power of Attorney?

A financial power of attorney is a legal document that grants someone other than yourself the authority to make financial decisions on your behalf. There are state-specific financial power of attorney forms that can be completed without an attorney; however, these documents are typically prepared with the assistance of an attorney as part of the estate planning process.

While the idea of giving someone the power to conduct business on your behalf may be alarming, that is what makes it so crucial for you to select someone you trust. If you were to become incapacitated, having this document allows someone to conduct financial business on your behalf.

One thing to understand about a financial power of attorney is that it is a document that only takes effect while you are living. Once you have passed on, this document is voided, and the executor of your estate now has the legal power to conduct business.

What is a Healthcare Directive?

A healthcare directive, also known as a living will, is a legal document that provides medical direction if you are no longer able to make decisions for yourself. This can be referred to by many names, such as healthcare power of attorney or durable power of attorney, but they serve the same purpose. 

There are state-specific health directive forms, or an attorney can draft one on your behalf. Healthcare directives can be challenging to consider, especially in the circumstances that would necessitate their implementation. Some of the decisions that may be included in a healthcare directive are:

do-not-resuscitate (DNR)

discontinuing life support

how you would like your body handled after death.

It is helpful to provide your healthcare provider with a copy of this document.

Each of these documents plays a unique role within an estate plan. 

At [REDACTED:ORG], our recommendation is to ensure that at minimum, you have a:

Will

Financial power of attorney

Healthcare directive

Once these documents are created, it’s essential to save them in a secure and accessible location (if you worked with an attorney, your attorney’s office will retain a 

copy) and share their existence and location with your loved ones and relevant professionals. 

Often-Overlooked Estate Planning Elements

In addition to the core legal documents described above, there are several estate planning elements that should be considered. Unfortunately, these tend to be overlooked, which can lead to complications for your beneficiaries.

What are Beneficiary Designations?

Beneficiary designations specify who you want to receive your assets upon your death. Beneficiary designations take precedent over directives written in your will, and they can help assets bypass the probate process. 

Reviewing your beneficiary designations regularly is crucial, especially after significant life changes, such as:

divorce

marriage

the birth of children

If your designations are outdated or incorrect, it can result in assets not being allocated to the intended recipients. It can also delay the probate process. 

By keeping your beneficiary designations up to date, you ensure that your assets are distributed according to your wishes and ease the process for your beneficiaries who are already grieving your loss.

What are Digital Assets?

When creating wills or other estate planning documents, the focus is often on tangible assets, such as a car, property, or heirlooms. However, in this generation, some of our 

most valuable assets are digital. Your estate plan must include instructions and relevant information to access your online accounts. This includes:

naming your accounts

providing passwords

specifying who you would like to have access to them

This can include anything from bank accounts to your social media accounts. Designating an individual to take control of your online presence after your death can also help prevent identity theft. 

Is Cryptocurrency a Digital Asset?

Cryptocurrency is often one of the first things that comes to mind when people hear the term “digital assets.” [REDACTED:ORG] recommends taking two crucial steps in estate planning if you own any cryptocurrency. First, track the information pertaining to your purchase of or access to cryptocurrency. This is important because unlike other financial assets, you do not have to provide your name or other personal information to purchase cryptocurrency. It is your responsibility to document your ownership of it. 

Inform your financial advisor and estate attorney of your cryptocurrency assets. This will help ensure this information is included in your estate plan. 

Second, ensure your heirs understand the tax implications of inheriting cryptocurrency. 

Including verbiage in your estate planning documents about this will prevent your heirs from inadvertently violating any laws.

What are the Most Important Digital Assets to Include in my Will?

Valuable digital assets include:

cryptocurrencies

domains

sentimental digital files like photos

These may be the most important digital assets to include in your will. Many states, including Minnesota, have adopted legislation that allows internet users to plan for the distribution of their digital assets. Many platforms have introduced features to do this, including [REDACTED:ORG] and [REDACTED:ORG]. 

For example, [REDACTED:ORG] recommend [REDACTED:ORG]’s “Legacy Contact” feature. This feature enables an account holder to designate individuals authorized to access their iCloud account after their passing. These selected individuals can use the account holder’s death certificate and an access key to bypass any court proceedings and gain access to the account holder’s iCloud files, contacts, notes, and other data. 

What is Business Succession Planning?

According to [REDACTED:ORG], many business owners view their business as their greatest asset. Thus, planning for the succession of their business is a critical part of a thorough estate plan. If a business is going to be left to the children of the owner, gifting ownership shares over an extended period can be a tax-efficient method of transferring ownership. Strategies that make effective use of federal gift and estate tax exclusions and exemptions can result in substantial tax savings. This means that despite the change in management, the business can retain its value. 

Is Life Insurance Part of Estate Planning?

Many people have life insurance, but don’t view it as part of their estate plan. With the right life insurance policy, you can leave your loved ones significant wealth and avoid the consequences of inheriting a large sum at one time. 

There are two different types of life insurance: 

term life insurance (provides coverage for a set amount of time)

permanent life insurance (lasts your entire life but typically costs significantly more)

There are pros and cons to each type. 

Life insurance can be used to pay estate taxes after your death. The payout can also be used in the case that you have assets that are not easily divisible. One heir could receive a life insurance payout in exchange for a property wholly going to another heir.

It is important to work with a financial planner when considering life insurance, because it can also add to your estate and the tax implications may not be worth it in the long run. 

Apart from life insurance, Medicaid and long-term care insurance are also something you need to consider while estate planning. According to [REDACTED:ORG], the median monthly cost for senior living in the state of Minnesota ranges from $2,100 to $13,200, and these costs are expected to continue rising. This is why it is crucial to begin planning for nursing homes, assisted living, or Medicaid eligibility as part of your estate planning process. 

What Funeral & Burial Preferences Should I Plan for?

If you have specific preferences for your funeral and burial arrangements, you can include them as part of your Estate Plan in a directive or letter of instruction. According to the [REDACTED:ORG], the average cost of a funeral in the United States is $8,300. This can vary based on your preferences, which is why it is crucial to inform your beneficiaries so they can prepare for the sometimes-hefty price tag. 

Taking care of funeral and burial costs ahead of time can help ease the grief of those you leave behind. Some funeral homes offer the option of a funeral trust, where individuals can pay for their funeral costs in advance, and any remaining funds are distributed to their beneficiaries. 

How do I Maintain my Estate Plan?

It is essential to regularly review and update your estate planning documents and accounts as your situation evolves or as current laws change. Below are some major life events that warrant reviewing and updating your estate plan.

Marriage or Divorce

When you get married or divorced, you may want to add or remove your spouse as a beneficiary. You can revise your healthcare directives and appoint or remove your spouse as your power of attorney.

Birth or Adoption of Children

Having children is one of the most important reasons to update your estate plan, because they will most likely outlive both you and your spouse. You’ll need to appoint guardians for them and possibly establish trusts to manage their inheritance. It may also be a good idea to designate powers of attorney for healthcare and financial decisions on their behalf.

Death of a Family Member

If a loved one passes away, you will need to update your estate plan by removing them as a beneficiary or a power of attorney. You’ll want to ensure that the estate plan remains effective without them. 

Financial Changes

If you’ve acquired new assets, such as property, investments, or businesses, you will need to update your estate plan to ensure they are distributed according to your wishes after your death. 

Legal Changes

There are federal and state laws governing estate planning, and if they change, you may need to update your estate plan to comply with these laws. If you move to a new state, you will likely need to update your estate plan to reflect the latest state laws.

Tax laws also change frequently and may impact estate taxes. Simply put, estate tax is a tax on the assets you leave behind when you die. The [REDACTED:ORG] looks at the total value of everything you own, and based on how large it is, you may owe taxes. 

Specific strategies, like charitable giving, can reduce the amount of taxes you owe. There are both federal and state estate taxes. The federal estate tax typically only applies to very large estates because of the higher exemption. 

Reviewing and updating your estate plan every few years is beneficial, even if there are no significant life changes. It is simply good practice to check in and keep your documents accessible and shared with the key people involved in your estate plan.

When Should I Consider Working With an Estate Planning Professional?

Financial planners often play a key role in the estate planning process. They understand the many variables that affect the distribution of assets after a death. They can help you create clear and actionable plans that will put all your loved ones on the same page by eliminating uncertainties, untangling discrepancies, and aligning your estate plan with your goals. 

Financial planners can work with you to facilitate your estate planning needs by:

narrowing down your intentions

communicating your objectives to your beneficiaries

preparing for documentation with a legal professional

A financial planner’s role doesn’t end once your estate plan is created; they can remain by your beneficiaries’ sides during the administration of your estate until all loose ends have been resolved. 

Having your financial planner collaborate directly with your estate attorney is also very helpful. [REDACTED:ORG] describes services provided by estate attorneys as including:

the preparation and administration of wills, trusts, powers of attorney, health care directives

charitable giving legalities

guardianships and conservatorships

resolution of family and business disputes

and more

A financial planner and estate attorney can collaborate and bring you the most comprehensive estate planning. 

At [REDACTED:ORG], we offer both estate planning and legacy planning services to help you safeguard your wealth, as well as help you crystallize your vision for the future. 

The Bottom Line

Many people lack an estate plan, which can result in a costly and emotional probate process. Key estate planning documents include:

wills

trusts

financial powers of attorney

healthcare directives

Having these documents in good order can help ensure your wishes are met and ease the process for your grieving loved ones. 

Are you ready to start estate planning? Do you need to update your estate plan? Consider partnering with a financial planner today. They can help you evaluate your current position, prioritize next steps, and create a customized plan for the rest of your life and beyond.

FAQ

1. Why do I need an estate plan?
Without one, your assets may be distributed by the state, which can be costly, slow, and stressful for your loved ones.

2. What documents should I have?
At minimum: a will, financial power of attorney, and healthcare directive. Trusts may also be useful in some cases.

3. How often should I update my estate plan?
Review your plan every few years or after major life events like marriage, divorce, or having children.

4. Should I work with a professional?
Yes—financial planners and estate attorneys can help ensure your plan works toward your goals, follows the law, and eases the process for your beneficiaries.
